The '''M74 tank recovery vehicle''' (M74)<ref>Spence. Army Vehicle Identification Numbers ISBN 0-938242-10-5</ref> was an engineer vehicle used by the [[United States|U.S. Army]] in the 1950s. It was designed to cope with the heavier weights of the [[M26 Pershing]] and [[M47 Patton]]. It could also be suitable for light dozing, since it had a hydraulic, front-mounted spade.<ref name=Berndt193 /> It was produced in the thousands by [[Bowen-McLaughlin-York]] and were also converted from M4A3 Shermans by Bowen starting in 1954. Later, some were converted from M32B1s by [[Rock Island Arsenal]] until 1958.<ref name=OD1 />
== Development ==
After the Korean War the M74 was designed to cope with the heavier weights of the new vehicles that were being introduced.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://afvdb.50megs.com/usa/trvm74.html | title=Medium Tank Recovery Vehicle M74 | publisher=Chris Conners | date=2011 | accessdate=5 April 2015 | author=Conners, Chris}}</ref><ref name=Skaarup172 />
Designed in 1953,<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ygqNt3ra-vYC&dq=m74+armored+recovery+vehicle&source=gbs_navlinks_s | title=Historical Dictionary of the U.S. Army | publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group | author=Brown, Jerold E. | year=2001 | location=Santa Barbara, CA | pages=27 | isbn=0-313-29322-8}}</ref> it based on the [[M4 Sherman|M4A3 HVSS]] medium tank, it was developed to cope with the heavier [[M26 Pershing]] and [[M47 Patton]] which were entering service, which the [[M32 tank recovery vehicle|M32 Armored Recovery Vehicle]] (ARV) was unable to retrieve. Using the standard [[Ford GAA engine|Ford GAA]] and wide tracks, the chassis would be rebuilt. It was replaced in service with the U.S. Army by the [[M88 Hercules]].<ref name=OD1>{{cite web|title=M74 Tank Recovery Vehicle – Olive Drab.com|url=http://olive-drab.com/idphoto/id_photos_recovery_m74.php|date=October 12, 2011 |accessdate=April 5, 2015|publisher=Olive Drab.com LLC}}</ref><ref name=Skaarup172 />
== Design == The M74 was fitted with a {{convert|60000|lb|kg|abbr=on}}<ref name=OD1 /><ref name=Skaarup172>Skaarup, Harold (2011), p. 172.</ref> hydraulic winch as well as a lighter-duty general purpose one, a hydraulic A-frame, and hydraulic front-mounted spade, which was suitable for light dozing, as well as serving as an anchor for heavy winching operations.<ref name=Berndt193>Berndt, Thomas. ''Standard Catalog of U.S. Military Vehicles'' (Krause Publications, 1993), p. 193.</ref><ref name=Chant21>Chant (2014), p. 21.</ref> It had a .50-caliber M2 machine gun atop the hull and a .30-cal M1919A4 machine gun in the right bow.
== Production == [[File:M74 in Ulm (Germany) 1954.jpg|250px|left|right|thumb|title|A M74 near Ulm, Germany, in 1954]] The M74 was produced from 1953 to 1955 by Bowen-McLaughlin-York in the thousands. The mass conversion of M4A3 Shermans into M74 recovery vehicles was started by Bowen in 1954.<ref>{{cite book |last=Doyle |first=David |date=2011 |title=Standard Catalog of U.S. Military Vehicles |edition=Second |location=Iola, WI |publisher=Krause Publications |isbn=1-4402-2572-9 |pages=417–418}}</ref> Some were also converted from old M32B1 ARVs by Rock Island Arsenal until 1958.<ref name=OD1 />
== Operators == * {{flag|United States}} – Used in post-World War II Germany. It was the standard recovery vehicle of the U.S. Army in the 1950s.<ref name=Skaarup172 /> * {{flag|Israel}} – Used in the [[Yom-Kippur War]]<ref name=Dunstan92>Dunstan, Simon (2007), p. 92.</ref> * {{flag|Spain}} – Lent by the United States from 1953 to 1968.<ref>Manrique, ''La Brunete'', p. 69</ref>
